title: 107_s3105
content: The Act may be cited as the "West Nile Virus and Arboviral Disease Act" and includes a temporary program for West Nile Virus and related arboviral diseases. Section 319 of the Public Health Service Act is amended to include a temporary program for West Nile Virus and related arboviral diseases. The Secretary can make grants to States for prevention and control, with a preference for states with a high incidence of West Nile Virus. The Secretary can make grants to States for prevention and control programs related to West Nile Virus and arboviral diseases. Preference may be given to states with a substantial incidence or prevalence of the virus or increased risk. Funds must be used for developing and implementing mosquito control plans at the community level. The grant program aims to support states in developing comprehensive mosquito control plans and programs on vector-borne diseases. States must provide assurances to the Secretary to be eligible for the grant. To be eligible for a grant under this program, a State must provide assurances to the Secretary that they will contribute non-Federal funds amounting to at least 50% of the program costs. Contributions can be in cash or in-kind. The grant requires non-Federal contributions of at least 50% of program costs, which can be cash or in-kind. Federal contributions or services subsidized by the Federal Government cannot be included. The grant must supplement, not supplant, State and local funds for similar activities. The Secretary has the authority to waive certain requirements. The grant must supplement, not supplant, State and local funds for similar activities. The Secretary may waive requirements for a State under extraordinary economic conditions. States receiving funds should involve localities in planning mosquito control plans. The grant under this subsection must be used for local public health improvement related to West Nile Virus or arboviral diseases. Technical assistance can be provided to enhance CDC's support for implementing and evaluating mosquito control programs. The Centers for Disease Control and Prevention provides technical support to State and local health departments for mosquito control programs and arboviral disease containment. Guidelines are developed in consultation with health and mosquito control organizations. Up to 20% of the funds allocated for this purpose can be used for this assistance. The Secretary, in consultation with health organizations, will develop guidelines for sustainable mosquito control programs at the state and local level. The guidelines will focus on identifying new disease cases and monitoring disease spread in mosquitoes, birds, and horses. The program established under this should include identifying new human cases of disease, tracking disease spread through monitoring various creatures, providing laboratory support, increasing participation in surveillance systems, conducting educational outreach campaigns, and outlining procedures for mosquito control and monitoring health/environmental effects. The Secretary will evaluate the program. The Secretary will conduct an evaluation of the program established under this subsection and submit a report to Congress within 18 months of the enactment of the West Nile Virus and Arboviral Disease Act. The report will include the evaluation results and information on developing a sustainable mosquito abatement program for states that have received it. The evaluation of the program established under this subsection will include information on developing a sustainable mosquito abatement program for states that have received funds. Authorization of appropriations is provided for fiscal years 2003 and 2004. Authorization of appropriations is provided for fiscal years 2003 and 2004 to carry out control programs in response to the West Nile Virus or related arboviruses. The program established under this subsection will terminate on September 30, 2004, unless extended by the Secretary based on evaluation. The Public Health Service Act is amended to include a new section for an Arbovirus Research Program. The President is required to enhance research to control insect populations transmitting diseases like West Nile Virus, develop screening tools, pathogen inactivation technologies, and containment methodologies. Activities may include examining existing methods and developing new ones. The President is mandated to enhance research on controlling insect populations transmitting diseases like West Nile Virus. Activities may involve examining current methods and developing new ones through various federal agencies and promoting coordination with relevant entities and experts in public health, entomology, arbovirology, and veterinary health. The President is required to promote coordination between federal agencies, the private sector, and experts in public health, entomology, arbovirology, and veterinary health. Authorization of appropriations is provided for fiscal years 2003 through 2007.
